title: How to Turn Broken Jewelry Into Magnets

steps.headline: Consider jewelry that is large enough to transform into a magnet.
steps.description: Even though you may have a piece that is precious it may not be large enough to make a singular statement. You could group smaller pieces together to make one large magnet or use the smaller pieces for another project.

steps.headline: Look for further damage to the jewelry.
steps.description: You want whole pieces that may have broken off a chain or hook but are still in good condition. Avoid using cracked or shattered pieces as they may be too delicate for everyday use.

steps.headline: Make sure none of the broken jewelry is extremely valuable.
steps.description: For example, you won’t want to turn a broken ruby ring into a magnet so be sure you separate the extremely valuable pieces from the rest.

steps.headline: Consider whether the jewelry needs professional cleaning before you create the magnet.
steps.description: Especially if the jewelry sat in a jewelry box for some time, it may have tarnished or could use a good polishing. Determine if it's a job you can do on your own with simply jewelry cleaner or if a professional should attempt to clean it.

steps.headline: Remove any hooks, pins or chains from the piece.
steps.description: You want the item to be a singular piece that makes a statement on its own. Use a pair of pliers or even scissors to remove any other hooks or pins before using.

steps.headline: Place a dab of glue on the backside of the magnet.
steps.description: You will want enough glue so the magnet adheres to the jewelry but not too much that it oozes out once you’ve joined the two.

steps.headline: Press the glued side of the magnet to the backside of the jewelry piece.
steps.description: Press gently and hold in place for a few seconds until the glue begins to adhere.

steps.headline: Place the jewelry in a safe spot for complete drying.

text: Evaluating the Broken Pieces Consider jewelry that is large enough to transform into a magnet. Even though you may have a piece that is precious it may not be large enough to make a singular statement. You could group smaller pieces together to make one large magnet or use the smaller pieces for another project. Look for further damage to the jewelry. You want whole pieces that may have broken off a chain or hook but are still in good condition. Avoid using cracked or shattered pieces as they may be too delicate for everyday use. Make sure none of the broken jewelry is extremely valuable. For example, you won’t want to turn a broken ruby ring into a magnet so be sure you separate the extremely valuable pieces from the rest. Consider whether the jewelry needs professional cleaning before you create the magnet. Especially if the jewelry sat in a jewelry box for some time, it may have tarnished or could use a good polishing. Determine if it's a job you can do on your own with simply jewelry cleaner or if a professional should attempt to clean it. Remove any hooks, pins or chains from the piece. You want the item to be a singular piece that makes a statement on its own. Use a pair of pliers or even scissors to remove any other hooks or pins before using. Making the Magnets Place a dab of glue on the backside of the magnet. You will want enough glue so the magnet adheres to the jewelry but not too much that it oozes out once you’ve joined the two. Press the glued side of the magnet to the backside of the jewelry piece. Press gently and hold in place for a few seconds until the glue begins to adhere. Place the jewelry in a safe spot for complete drying.  Finished.
